message: "Let’s suppose I am an Islamic State terrorist. I don’t do bombs or bullets. I leave the dirty work to the crazies in the basement. My job is what happens next. It is to turn carnage into consequences, body parts into politics. I am a consultant terrorist. I wear a suit, not explosives. A blood-stained concourse is a means to an end. The end is power. This week I had another success. I converted a squalid psychopathological act into a warrior-evoking, population-terrifying, policy-changing event."

attachment.caption: theguardian.com
attachment.description: Paolo Macchiarini is alleged to have continued with new method of windpipe surgery despite it not working, with six of eight patients later dying

message:
The criticisms kept coming. Last month, an article published in Vanity Fair magazine claimed Paolo Macchiarini had embellished his academic credentials from a number of universities around Europe, and had made false claims about being part of “highly classified group of doctors from around the world who cater to the world’s VIPs”, including Pope Francis, Hilary Clinton, Emperor Akihito of Japan, and Barack Obama.

On 11 July 2015, Macchiarini had been due to marry Benita Alexander, a US television producer he had met while she was making a documentary about his work. According to Vanity Fair, the Switzerland-born Italian scientist had told Alexander that Vladimir Putin, Barack and Michelle Obama, the Clintons, Nicolas Sarkozy and tenor Andrea Bocelli were all planning to attend their wedding.

As if that wasn’t enough, the pope himself would host the ceremony, Macchiarini reportedly said.

Sick children dying as lifesaving medicine waits at checkpoints, youngsters forced to survive on animal feed and leaves, and families burning their mattresses just to find something to keep them warm.

attachment.caption: theguardian.com
attachment.description: For the last eight years, Gift and her husband Abu have spent most of their married life on the road fighting FGM in south-east Nigeria

like_info.message: In Ugep, a village in Nigeria, there is a large tree that towers over the children standing next to it. Around its trunk are ribbons of cloth used to tie young girls who had reached puberty, in preparation for their clitoris and labia to be cut off in the public square as part of a ritual to symbolise their entry into womanhood. Gift Abu and her husband have spent the past 8 years working to end this practice.

like_info.message: "Street harassment, misogyny and racism are a daily occurrence for black women in this country. If we are not on the receiving end of those then we are treated as if we are invisible. I could give several accounts of situations where I have been outright ignored and then the very thing I said repeated by a white man and given praise. When you challenge that behaviour you are then called an “angry black woman” or told that you are “too proud”. We all need to be more open to listening to each other and stop building defences when someone challenges us on our behaviours that oppress others."

media.alt: As the era of true artificial intelligence draws closer, the problem of a shared language rears its head

attachment.name: Will we ever really talk with the machines?
attachment.caption: theguardian.com
attachment.description: As the era of true artificial intelligence draws closer, the problem of a shared language rears its head

like_info.message: 'How will we communicate with computers? Easy, peasy, say the AI evangelists: we’ll just talk to them just like we talk to one another. At this point, a whirring noise can be heard: it’s Ludwig Wittgenstein rotating at 5,000rpm in his grave. “What can be said at all can be said clearly,” he wrote in the Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus, “and what we cannot talk about we must pass over in silence.” And therein lies the problem. Because often what really matters to us humans is stuff that we have difficulty articulating.'

like_info.message: "To those not in the know, he would introduce himself as Robert Hunt. But Robert Hunt wasn’t really Robert Hunt at all. He was Frank Terpil, rogue CIA agent. A man described as a “maniac” by the undercover US policeman who helped convict him in New York in 1981 on charges of seeking to sell 10,000 machine-guns and 20 tonnes of plastic explosives to Libya. A coldly intelligent, no-scruples dealmaker, and confidant of the later 20th century’s most brutal dictators, from the Shah of Iran to Idi Amin."

like_info.message: "Territorialists like Donald J. Trump suggest that people can have their cake and eat it: disrupt globalisation and stay rich, minimise investment in international affairs and remain safe and free. They take the huge gains in prosperity, security and freedom of the last decades for granted. They fail to understand that those gains depend on massive investments of nation states in international order, and that globalisation is based on open societies and increasingly easy cross-border flows of goods, people and information."

Is Nuts magazine still going and now sponsoring Mother’s Day? media.alt: Some children see only things to hate about the way they look. Their condition can lead to depression, anxiety, self-surgery and even suicide, reports Eva Wiseman

attachment.name: The ugly truth about body dysmorphia
attachment.caption: theguardian.com
attachment.description: Some children see only things to hate about the way they look. Their condition can lead to depression, anxiety, self-surgery and even suicide, reports Eva Wiseman

like_info.message: "A man took a razor blade and very carefully cut open his nose. His aim was to remove the cartilage and replace it with that of a chicken. Finally, he’d feel so much better. A man took a hammer to his face. Somebody cut the ends of their fingers off. Across the world people are standing in bathrooms with knives, quietly hating themselves. Self-surgery is one of the hallmarks of body dysmorphic disorder, where a person has a distorted view of how they look. A nose, a hand. A place to focus on, and to hate."

like_info.message: She was born on the top bunk in the barracks of camp C at Auschwitz-Birkenau in December 1944. She had weighed just 1kg and was too weak to cry. Sixty years later she finally broke her silence. Last week she took one of her most courageous decisions yet, to take to the witness stand in the case of a 94-year-old former SS guard, in what will be one of the last from the Nazi concentration camps. The incredible story of Angela Orosz.

media.alt: We have 5,000 euphemisms for menstruation, but we still can’t talk about them openly – and stop the stigma that’s harming women’s health and education

attachment.name: Bad blood: the taboo on talking about periods is damaging lives
attachment.caption: theguardian.com
attachment.description: We have 5,000 euphemisms for menstruation, but we still can’t talk about them openly – and stop the stigma that’s harming women’s health and education

like_info.message: "Whatever it takes to bring periods out of the realm of secret and hidden is fine with me. But euphemisms are fine with me too. It would be nice if we were capable of talking more clearly about our bodies. But what’s damaging the lives of millions is not daft and coy terms for periods, but being unable to talk about them at all, or being so ashamed that they have to dry their sanitary cloths under the beds or in the damp, getting urinary infections or worse."

media.alt: Being one of only four million ‘leaplings’ in the world born on 29 February means feeling both a different and unique – and also prompts lots of questions

attachment.name: Growing up as a leap year baby: 'kids would say I didn’t have a real birthday'
attachment.caption: theguardian.com
attachment.description: Being one of only four million ‘leaplings’ in the world born on 29 February means feeling both a different and unique – and also prompts lots of questions

like_info.message: "My 12th birthday was met with “hilarious” comments from friends about how really I was only three, a joke that still continues today. I’ve lost count of the childish birthday cards I’ve received on leap-year birthdays with garish badges proclaiming an age that’s only a quarter of the one I’m actually turning. On non-leap years, friends would often simply forget my birthday, or more cruelly, revel in telling me I didn’t have one."

Ilhan Omar is unsure if it was seven or eight people who held her down and repeatedly hit her at a Minnesota party caucus in 2014.

Two years after the attack, which left Omar with a concussion, she is returning to that same district caucus as a candidate.

media.alt: Like Pat Buchanan and Ross Perot before him, the Republican frontrunner plays on voters’ worst fears. But the toxicity of his message – and his success – far eclipses theirs

attachment.name: Trump's rise is the return of the demagogue
attachment.caption: theguardian.com
attachment.description: Like Pat Buchanan and Ross Perot before him, the Republican frontrunner plays on voters’ worst fears. But the toxicity of his message – and his success – far eclipses theirs

like_info.message: "Donald J. Trump's applause lines come right out of the same demagogue’s playbook that George Wallace used. The definition of the word, with roots in ancient Greece, is a 'political leader who seeks support by appealing to popular desires and prejudices rather than by using rational argument.'"

media.alt: His film is lazy, teenage nonsense that doesn’t warrant any outrage, least of all in the town I have fond memories of

attachment.name: Baron Cohen’s Grimsby isn’t offensive – it’s worse than that | Gaby Hinsliff
attachment.caption: theguardian.com
attachment.description: His film is lazy, teenage nonsense that doesn’t warrant any outrage, least of all in the town I have fond memories of

like_info.message: "Grimsby isn’t my hometown, but my memories of living there are all good ones, and I admire its heroically stubborn refusal to go under in hard times. Leaving aside the awkwardness of a millionaire comedian rinsing its poverty for cheap laughs, the last thing it needs is anything that might put companies off relocating there and bringing jobs."

attachment.name: The best of what you missed at the Oscars

like_info.message:
If you missed Oscars 2016 coverage online and on TV, we’ve collected the top five moments for you catch up on. 

From behind the scenes exclusives on YouTube, to headline speeches and sideline action almost everyone missed, here are the highlights.

like_info.message: "The croissant is only acceptable as a breakfast food and, unless you live a life of gilded luxury, only at weekends. This is a matter of time, cost and the fact that if you eat them regularly you will collapse of a heart attack at an unfashionably young age."

media.alt: To mark 150 years since the author’s birth, Beatrix Potter’s much-loved bunny becomes the first character from children’s literature to appear on a UK coin

attachment.name: Beatrix Potter's Peter Rabbit gets his own 50p coin – and he didn't have to steal it
attachment.caption: theguardian.com
attachment.description: To mark 150 years since the author’s birth, Beatrix Potter’s much-loved bunny becomes the first character from children’s literature to appear on a UK coin

like_info.message:
The Royal Mint has chosen Beatrix Potter’s thieving Peter Rabbit as the first character from children’s literature ever to appear on a UK coin.

Peter, pictured in the blue jacket that he is forced to abandon in the garden of Mr McGregor when he is caught stealing vegetables, is captured on a special, coloured edition of the 50p coin available from today.

media.alt: Alicia Vikander goes girly and Cate Blanchett comes dressed as a mermaid … Hollywood’s leading women opted for a decidedly girly look on the red carpet

attachment.name: Oscars red carpet: a retrograde year for Hollywood feminism
attachment.caption: theguardian.com
attachment.description: Alicia Vikander goes girly and Cate Blanchett comes dressed as a mermaid … Hollywood’s leading women opted for a decidedly girly look on the red carpet

like_info.message: "Red carpet glamour long ago departed from what counts as party dressing in the real world. (You can tell that from the vocabulary, which is all “goddess dress” this and “fairytale gown” that.) But this year, the look was less champagne-sipping glamour than unadulterated sugar."

like_info.message: After they finished shooting a disembowelment, Greg Nicotero drove home covered in blood. “Every stop sign we pulled up at, I looked over at the driver in the next car. Freaked everybody out! God, I love my job.”

attachment.name: Move to Kings Place
attachment.caption: Move to Kings Place
attachment.description: Guardian News & Media moves to its new home at Kings Place

attachment.name: Digital archive
attachment.caption: Digital archive
attachment.description: The Guardian and Observer digital archive is launched, the first example of a national UK newspaper making its paper archive available online via its website.

attachment.name: Berliner
attachment.caption: Berliner
attachment.description: The new Berliner Guardian launches, with a ground-breaking design in a mid-size format. The Guardian becomes the UK's first full-colour national newspaper, and the first UK national newspaper ever to adopt this size.

media.alt: The Newsroom, Guardian and Observer Archive and Visitor Centre, opens its doors. The centre preserves and promotes the histories and values of the newspapers through its archive, educational programmes and exhibitions. The Newsroom's activities all transfer to Kings Place in 2008.

attachment.name: The newsroom
attachment.caption: The newsroom
attachment.description: The Newsroom, Guardian and Observer Archive and Visitor Centre, opens its doors. The centre preserves and promotes the histories and values of the newspapers through its archive, educational programmes and exhibitions. The Newsroom's activities all transfer to Kings Place in 2008.
The Guardian wins widespread acclaim for its coverage of the events of 11 September proclaimed "bold, simple and courageous" at the British Press Awards.

attachment.name: Welcome to the webz: Guardian unlimited
attachment.caption: Welcome to the webz: Guardian unlimited
attachment.description: Guardian Unlimited network of websites is launched in January 1999 and quickly becomes one of the UK's most popular newspaper websites, growing dramatically over the following years. Guardian Unlimited is renamed guardian.co.uk in 2008.

attachment.name: Remembering Princess Diana
attachment.caption: Remembering Princess Diana
attachment.description: A special Saturday edition of the Observer to mark the death of Princess Diana on 31 August 1997

attachment.name: 'A liar and a cheat'
attachment.caption: 'A liar and a cheat'
attachment.description: The Guardian's investigation into conservative MP Neil Hamilton wins the Team Reporting Award at the British Press Awards and the Guardian is named Newspaper of the Year by What the Papers Say, an award it also wins in 1998 and 1999.

attachment.name: Alan Rusbridger becomes editor
attachment.caption: Alan Rusbridger becomes editor
attachment.description: Alan Rusbridger becomes editor. He is still currently editor-in-chief.

attachment.name: Guardian Media Group acquires the Observer
attachment.caption: Guardian Media Group acquires the Observer
attachment.description:
Faced with the acquisition of a natural ally by a major competitor, the Guardian Media Group acquired the Observer in 1993. As a result the Observer has been able to maintain its editorial independence, ensuring the continuation of the paper's long-standing tradition of liberal politics and independent journalism.

The Observer has continued its reputation for setting, rather than following the news agenda, breaking stories including exposing the cash-for-access scandal dubbed Lobbygate, and leading the way in covering of issues like GM foods and cloning.

attachment.name: Redesign and Guardian Weekend
attachment.caption: Redesign and Guardian Weekend
attachment.description: The Guardian has a radical redesign, splitting the newspaper into two sections and introducing a new masthead. An international edition is launched in Europe and the Weekend section is published for the first time.

attachment.name: Sarah Tisdall case
attachment.caption: Sarah Tisdall case
attachment.description: A Foreign and Commonwealth Office clerical officer gives the Guardian documents on the movement of nuclear weapons. The Guardian is taken to court and ordered to reveal their source and Sarah Tisdall is imprisoned for six months.

attachment.name: 119 Farringdon Road
attachment.caption: 119 Farringdon Road
attachment.description: The Guardian moves from Gray's Inn Road to its own offices at 119 Farringdon Road, which are to be home to the paper for the next 32 years.

attachment.name: Peter Preston appointed editor
attachment.caption: Peter Preston appointed editor
attachment.description: Peter Preston is appointed editor, a post he is to hold for 20 years.

attachment.name: New home at Cross Street
attachment.caption: New home at Cross Street
attachment.description: On 29 August the Guardian's Manchester office moves from its home in Cross Street to new offices in nearby Deansgate. The Guardian had been written and printed from this office since 1886.

attachment.name: Inside Cross Street
attachment.caption: Inside Cross Street
attachment.description: The subeditors' room at Cross Street

attachment.name: Inside Cross Street
attachment.caption: Inside Cross Street
attachment.description: This picture was taken between 1969 and 1970 and shows the Subeditors room at Cross Street

attachment.name: Move from Manchester to London
attachment.caption: Move from Manchester to London
attachment.description: The editor's office and major editorial departments relocate from Manchester to London. The London office is in Gray's Inn Road where the Guardian has been printing since 1961, and is shared with The Sunday Times.

attachment.name: JFK assassinated
attachment.caption: JFK assassinated
attachment.description: Front page of the Guardian after the shooting of US president John F Kennedy

attachment.name: Man on the moon
attachment.caption: Man on the moon
attachment.description: How the Guardian reported the moon landing

attachment.name: Printing in London: 'The Graun' is born
attachment.caption: Printing in London: 'The Graun' is born
attachment.description: To enable swifter delivery of the Guardian to southern England the newspaper begins printing in London as well as Manchester on 11 September 1961. Difficulties with the printing system earn the newspaper the nickname 'The Grauniad'.

attachment.name: Manchester Guardian becomes the Guardian
attachment.caption: Manchester Guardian becomes the Guardian
attachment.description: On 24 August 1959 the newspaper changes its title from the Manchester Guardian to the Guardian, to reflect the growing importance of national and international affairs in the newspaper.

attachment.name: Inside Manchester Guardian
attachment.caption: Inside Manchester Guardian
attachment.description: More images from the subs room

attachment.name: In the sub's room
attachment.caption: In the sub's room
attachment.description:
Here's an image of the Manchester Guardian subeditors' room

Photograph: Adolf Morath
Manchester Guardian

attachment.name: Suez crisis
attachment.caption: Suez crisis
attachment.description: Alastair Hetherington becomes editor following Wadsworth's death. He is strongly against the government's military action in Suez and in contrast to the majority of the British press the Guardian is consistently critical of the invasion.

attachment.name: Death of King George VI
attachment.caption: Death of King George VI
attachment.description: The front page of the Manchester Guardian after the death of King George VI

attachment.name: News on the front page
attachment.caption: News on the front page
attachment.description: On WP Crozier's death, Alfred Powell Wadsworth become editor. During his editorship the Manchester Guardian puts news on the front page in place of classified ads for the first time, and circulation more than doubles to over 168,000 copies a day.

attachment.name: Edward's abdication
attachment.caption: Edward's abdication
attachment.description: King Edward VIII renounces the throne. "The King never wavered," reports the Manchester Guardian.

attachment.name: The Scott Trust is born
attachment.caption: The Scott Trust is born
attachment.description: Ownership of the Guardian is transferred to a trust to protect the newspaper from crippling death duties following the untimely death of Ted Scott. His brother John creates the Scott Trust to ensure the independence of the newspaper and the continuance of the journalistic principles of his father, CP Scott.

attachment.name: Inside Manchester Guardian
attachment.caption: Inside Manchester Guardian
attachment.description: This is the stereo department

attachment.name: WP Crozier
attachment.caption: WP Crozier
attachment.description: CP Scott dies in January 1932, followed only three months later by his son Ted Scott who is killed in a tragic boating accident. William Perceival Crozier is appointed as editor in place of Ted Scott, a position he is to hold until his death in 1944.

attachment.name: Ted Scott takes over as editor
attachment.caption: Ted Scott takes over as editor
attachment.description: CP Scott retires after 57 years as editor, and his son Edward (Ted) Scott takes over. Ted joined the Manchester Guardian in 1913, and had already made his mark as labour correspondence and a leader writer before taking on the editorship in 1929.

attachment.name: Inside Manchester Guardian
attachment.caption: Inside Manchester Guardian

attachment.name: An advert for the Guardian's centenary issue in 1921
attachment.caption: An advert for the Guardian's centenary issue in 1921

attachment.name: First Guardian weekly
attachment.caption: First Guardian weekly
attachment.description: On 4 July 1919 Guardian Weekly is launched to provide a compact weekly edition of the newspaper

attachment.name: The Amazing Truce: Christmas in the trenches
attachment.caption: The Amazing Truce: Christmas in the trenches
attachment.description: The Guardian reports on an unlikely truce in the trenches: "'On Christmas Eve both troops were singing to one another, and on Christmas morning after some shouted conversation across the open space between the trenches a German shouted: "Be British and come half-way!" and out goes one of our officers.'"

attachment.name: Walter Doughty
attachment.caption: Walter Doughty
attachment.description: Walter Doughty is appointed as the Guardian's first staff photographer, reflecting the growing importance of photography in newspapers. An innovative  and talented photojournalist he is to work for the paper until his death in the 1950s.

attachment.name: CP Scott becomes both owner and editor
attachment.caption: CP Scott becomes both owner and editor
attachment.description: Following the death of John Edward Taylor's son in 1905 CP Scott buys the Guardian. He is both owner and editor
